instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1502: What is A1502? A1502 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2014, Late 2013, Early 2015 with EMC 2875, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3476, 820-3536, 820-4924..
definitions.A1278: What is A1278? A1278 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook or Macbook Pro Unibody from years Late 2008, Mid 2009, Mid 2010, Early 2011, Late 2011, Mid 2012 with EMC 2254, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-2327, 820-2530, 820-2879, 820-2936, 820-3115..
definitions.820-4924: What is 820-4924? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.BKLT_EN_R: What is BKLT_EN_R? This signal enables backlight. Anytime you see a signal ending with “_EN” , that means this signal being present/high enables what it is referring to. This signal says “BKL” before “_EN”. “BKL” sounds short for “BACKLIGHT”, so it is safe to assume this signal enables backlight when present. The “_R” suffix means that the signal is asserted when it is high, as in 3.3v, which is the opposite of the “_L”  suffix.
definitions.BKLT_SDA: What is BKLT_SDA? BKLT_SDA is a data line between the LCD screen and the LED driver. This data line cannot short to ground. If it does, the screen cannot talk to the LED driver, and the LED driver will not allow the circuit to produce a backlight..
definitions.A1466: What is A1466? A1466 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Air from years Early 2015, 2017, Mid 2012, Mid 2013, Early 2014 with EMC 2925, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00165, 820-3209, 820-3437..
definitions.820-4668: What is 820-4668? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.A1398: What is A1398? A1398 is a model number for a 15 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Mid 2015, Mid 2012, Early 2013, Late 2013, Mid 2014 with EMC 2909, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-00138, 820-00163, 820-00426, 820-3332, 820-3662, 820-3787..
definitions.820-3787: What is 820-3787? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>

No image on screen, BUT with external monitor its working 100% fine

SINCE I do not have same MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen to test and check if its BAD screen. Is there any other test that I could make?

Can I test an old <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> screen on this model to check?

Any other method to test before going to buy a new screen without 100% being SURE?

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
<MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> models use LVDS screens, and <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> eDP instead.
More than that, 2015 model is unique; not compatible with previous <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> variants.
Not sure what board do you have there; is a must post in the title.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
Hi

Its a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-4924</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A

Tested with a new screen and same behavior!

BTW the camera work fine!! 

Looks like its something bad on the board!

2015 LCD assembly for sure?
It is not compatible with previous <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> from 2013/14.

threads.message: I can record a video if you want!

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
New doesn't mean known good.
With original screen missing image and backlight at same time?

Do you get 3V at pin 5/J8300?
Also check for 5V at pins 28-30, at least in the first seconds (when chimes).
<SIGNAL>LCD_HPD_CONN</SIGNAL> should go high at same time; if LCD is connected and correctly recognized.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
Just noticed with the new screen that is a backlight problem.

Where should I look for?

Weird that with the original screen I didnt get a backlight problem

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
As I said, you must be sure this screen is for 2015.
Or you never get backlight.
Find another KNOWN GOOD 2015 screen for test.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
I bought described as 2015 BRAND NEW... I am not sure if its KNOWN GOOD cause I do not have another computer to test to

However the original one doesnt have backlight and image
this BRAND NEW doesnt have backlight

What options do I have?

Buy another one? LOL  I am out of money I bought this one after coming here asking for solution

To really test with a KIND OF KNOW GOOD since its a new one

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
Known good no need to be perfect.
Keep damaged screens for test in service.
Broken screen, but which you know got backlight before replaced is perfect for test.
The problem is to mark the compatible year on the broken test screens; once you remove from the machine.

Do you actually get any voltage at pin 1/J8300?
<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> is present?

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
I do not have any broken screen for this model to keep and test. I usually keep broken stuff if is TESTABLE.

PIN 1 J8300 = 0V
BKLT-<SIGNAL>EN_R</SIGNAL> = I measured on a TP on the side of the board, since the components are on the back of the board and not possible to measure without dissamble it. I hope this TP is related to the backlight

If you see the picture of the board its the only one that appears below L7720 and it gives me 4.50V

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
You may need to check more points on the backlight circuit.
Some of them will be available ONLY on the other side.

The boardview shows many more test points in that area; not seen on your picture.
Are you sure that is <SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> and not <SIGNAL>BKLT_SDA</SIGNAL>???

"Fastest way" will be to test with known good compatible screen.
You may waste time with a good working board in fact.
Try to find 13" 2015 broken screen (with good backlight) in other service center, or second hand auction websites.
Is good to have it in stock for future repairs.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message: You can find the backlight chip on <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> and newer machines, 2016-2019.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
I replaced with a backlight chip from a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1398</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3787</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> donor board but still no backlight.


<SIGNAL>BKLT_EN_R</SIGNAL> = 3.32v 


What now?

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
Check all resistors and traces around <CHIP>U7700</CHIP>.
Post voltage for pins 5, 18, 11, 15, 16.
You may try changing <TRANSISTOR>Q7701</TRANSISTOR>.
Be sure <DIODE>D7710</DIODE> is not shorted A-K.

Remember, check voltages with LCD connected.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
F7700 does not have continuity can I replace it with a fuse from a <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1278</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> donor board? 

The funny thing is if its a backlight issue as we checked and saw it with the brand new screen that I bought

WHY with the original screen it doesnt give image and I am not able to check with a flash light as it happens with the BRAND NEW screen?

Really weird!

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
You can replace the fuse with 3A fuse, or just a tiny wire (0.1mm).
Be sure first no short, or wrong resistance to ground on any pin of <DIODE>D7710</DIODE>.

Maybe original screen has image problem; or not easy to detect with flashlight.

threads.title: MBP <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1502</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> no image on screen
threads.message:
Replace fuse and with original screen nothing happened.

With the brand new screen that you were think was not working

ITS 100% FINE

Weird situation to have backlight and screen damaged, right?
